title: Investigate fisheye lense or other rounding effects for board rendering
Alternate board schemes

labels.name: theme:game-mechanics
labels.description: Possible new rules or tricks, not code-oriented

body:
Possible boards:
- Plane tesselations
  - 6x3-board "super hexagon"
  - Multiple hexagons (maybe 4 hexagon "diamond")
  - Octagon/square alternation
- Platonic solids
  - 6x4-board cube
  - 6x1-board minicube
  - 4x3 tetrahedron
  - 8x3 octohedron
  - 12x5 dodecahedron
  - 20x3 icosahedron

Previous assumptions that are violated:
- Larger boards could have smaller regions. Maybe 3 cells wide instead of 5.
- Platonic solids and the "super hexagon" would include circuit paths.
- 6x4 cube, icosahedron, octahedron and maybe others would have voids with different numbers of regions
- More than one void
- Clockwise/c-clockwise cannot be used to describe inter-region relationships. N/S/E/W can be used instead since regions are squares. N/S and E/W would not be reversible though. R1 may be N of R2 from R1s perspective but R2 may be E of R1 from R2s perspective.
- Region count != max player count
- Player start locations
- No outside edge for some boards or regions

body: This would allow clients to animate the piece moving through each cell, around warped parts of thr board.

title: Consider ditching Giraffe
body: It doesn't really seem like Giraffe is still providing much value. As the API has grown, a fully functional style has proven cumbersome, and using object-oriented patterns and dependency injection at higher scopes has been necessary to manage complexity. Since the HTTP layer of the API is already organized into controller classes, there is really very little Giraffe still in it. It might be simpler to ditch Giraffe altogether and just use vanilla ASP.NET Core.

- Friend icon to display next to user names in different contexts.
- Public user profile page?

title: Add "current player name" column and filter to search

labels.name: theme:usability
labels.description: Making the UI easier to use or understand

body:
This is more difficult than it sounds because currently the turn cycle is serialized as JSON in SQL. 

Possible solutions
- Use T-SQL JSON features.
- Persist turn cycle data in a relational way.
- Make the game search endpoint also query SQL for the players of games returned from the first SQL query, then append the current player or filter by the current player.

title: Consider breaking up monolithic Redux actions/reducers
body:
Most actions only modify one part of the state. There are a few that modify more than one, and logout clears everything. These monoliths are all in the root store module. 

Consider splitting these up into smaller actions that modify smaller pieces of state, and then dispatch multiple actions at the same time in `Controller`.

title: Change route for "start game"
body: Now that there is a `PUT /games/{id}/players/{id}/status/{status}` endpoint, it would be nice to also model game statuses in a similar way.  Instead of `POST /games/{id}/start-request` there would be `PUT /games/{id}/status/{status}`. The only currently supported status change would be `Pending` -> `InProgress`.  Canceling could also be done through this endpoint by changing `Pending` -> `Canceled`.  Currently that is supported by deleting the player who created the game `DELETE /games/{id}/players/{id}`

title: Consider some consolation prize for players other than the last one alive

labels.name: theme:game-mechanics
labels.description: Possible new rules or tricks, not code-oriented

labels.name: theme:usability
labels.description: Making the UI easier to use or understand

body:
This could be realized in different ways.

**Possibility 1: Post-game points tally, like in Starcraft.**

Points would be counted based on the effects of events that had happened throughout the game. (Ex: killing a piece is 1 point, eliminating a player is 5 points, etc.) This would create a "last player standing" official winner, but also an honorable mention "highest score" winner. 

This could improve the experience in the case where one player plays very well the whole game but gets eliminated late in the game by a player who was been doing poorly.  The player who was eliminated still gets to claim "high score", while the player who did the eliminating gets to claim "last standing".

Like in Starcraft, where points for destroying building and points for killing units are subtotaled separately, the points could be subtotaled by effect kind. This would also let you see which player killed the most pieces, or tossed the most corpses with a gravedigger, etc.  This would allow even more players to feel like they are partial winners. This could balance the high loss ratio to be expected in 6-8 player games.

This is also similar to how Chess is scored sometimes, where capturing a pawn is 1 point, knight is 3, bishop and rook are 5, etc. (I think that's how it goes...)

Possible point values:
- Kill a thug: 1pt
- Kill a reporter, gravedigger, assassin, or diplomat: 3pts
- Kill a chief: 5pts
- Enlist a piece: 1pt (this means killing a chief is really 5+Npts)
- Move a piece with a diplomat or gravedigger: 1pt
- End a turn with your chief in the seat: 1pt
- Last player standing: 10pts

**Possibility 2: Badges/achievements**

Badges would be little icons that show up next to a players name, and are maybe included in a post-game summary based on accomplishing different goals during a game.  

Each badge would be scoped to the context of one game.  So if there was a badge for killing 5 pieces, you could get that badge in each game after killing 5 pieces in that game, but not after killing 1 piece in 5 different games.

Badges could be awarded during the game, as the effects triggered by a player fulfill the goal required for the badge. They could be announced as a new effect attached to events.

Like having point category subtotals in _Possibility 1_, badges would allow many players to feel like they are accomplishing things, even if they aren't the last player standing.  They could also be used to declare an honorable mention winner at the end, possibly just "most badges".

One important difference with badges is that it would add in-game incentives (or distractions), whereas a post-game points summary would not.  (Badges could also be hidden until the end of the game, but that's a little non-idiomatic of badge/achievement systems.)

A great benefit of badges is that they could be used to encourage different styles of play.  For example, there could be a badge for tossing 5 corpses with a gravedigger, which might get a player to try that piece out more.

Possible badges:
- Kill 5 pieces
- Kill 10 pieces
- Kill 20 pieces
- Kill a chief
- Toss 5 corpses with a gravedigger
- Toss 5 pieces with a diplomat
- Kill 5 pieces with an assassin
- Kill 5 pieces with a reporter
- Kill 5 pieces with a chief
- Rise to power
- Stay in power for 5 of your turns
- Put another player's chief in power with your diplomat
- Get a chief out of power with an assassin
- Enlist 10 pieces

title: Handle all unions in JsonConverters and Client Generator
body:
Currently only these unions are supported
- Options 
- "Enum" unions
- Unions where each case has only 1 field.

Support should be added for unions with multiple fields. These should be serialized like single-field unions, but with an array for the `value` property.

There is no immediate need for this

body:
This would make the tuple `(PlayerID, GameID)` the primary key of `Players`.  

The benefit of this is that the IDs could be useful to users in the UI.  The cost is that any use of these IDs must also check the GameID.

labels.name: theme:game-mechanics
labels.description: Possible new rules or tricks, not code-oriented

Depends on #50 

With events being logged, it should be possible to "undo" events and scroll back in time in the game.   This requires further consideration of how this would be useful to clients.

title: Create API contract tests
body: API unit and integration tests should also be separated

title: Add player messaging

labels.name: theme:game-mechanics
labels.description: Possible new rules or tricks, not code-oriented

body:
Players need the ability to send messages within a game in order to form alliances or negotiate.  

There must be the ability to send a message that all other players can see.  

Maybe direct messages to a single player should be allowed, but this may stray from the "no hidden information" mindset of the game.  The game-wide messaging should be implemented in a way so that direct messaging can be added later, if desired.

Lobby messaging would be nice to have as well.

There is already a `Messages` table in SQL, but the API is not really using it yet.  Its structure may need to be modified if it is used for all 3 messaging types.

title: Add animation effects + sounds for in game actions

labels.name: theme:game-mechanics
labels.description: Possible new rules or tricks, not code-oriented

body:
It would be nice if there were visual effects or sounds when different game actions happened.

Examples:
- Smooth piece movement from starting cell to destination cell
- Piece flipped over when being killed and turning into Corpse
- Maybe each piece has a special effect when it targets another piece
    - Thug makes a punch sound
    - Gravedigger makes a shovel sound
    - Diplomat makes a "whoosh" sound
    - Assassin makes a stab sound
    - Reporter makes a typewriter sound?
    - Chief makes some chiefy sound?
- Maybe killing a piece always makes the same effect regardless of which piece type did the killing, same with moving a piece
- Effect when a Chief rises and falls from power
- Effect when a player is eliminated
- Effect when a player wins
- Maybe a special effect when a Chief dies from have 0 moves or being surrounded

This will require new data to be returned by the API, like a list of changes to the game state after a turn, or a list of cells that a piece moves through.
